Oct 19 2009 	Perfect in every way!	Beautiful old hotel. The best of everything from service to food to room...you name it, every possible luxury was provided...happily. Probably the nicest hotel experience I have ever had! I arrived after 3 weeks of traveling with a group and I was down to my last nerve. I did not have a reservation but the gentleman at the desk quickly picked up that I needed some pampering and gave me a BEAUTIFUL suite and some much needed TLC.

Mar 3 2009 	Wanted to see what it was all about	We liked the Savoy, it was beautiful and the room was large and nicely decorated (traditionally speaking). We stayed for 1 night as we wanted to check out a higher-end historic hotel for our last night before flying back to Ottawa. With FX rates what they are, and the fact that London hotels are expensive anyway we ended up paying close to $500 CAD for the night. I think I was expecting more for the price - maybe a bit more of a "wow" factor, but overall we thought the hotel was fine. Great location for sure, close to the Tube. I think next time we visit London we'll look for something less expensive and more modern, but that has more to do with taste and lifestyle than the fact that we found something wrong with this hotel.

Nov 21 2008 	The icon of historic London hotels	[Of note, this review is of (somewhat) historical significance due to the renovations due to be completed in 2009.] Length of stay: 11 nightsCheck-in: Taxi from the train station to the hotel. Flawless check in. The porter (Tony) was the consummate professional, offering to pay the taxi for me when the cab had misplaced my fare. Accomodations: Basic single room befitting a single traveller who came to London to see the sights. The room was clean and functional. VERY nice bathroom with walk-in shower. I agree with earlier reviewers that the hotel in general was beginning to show its wear, especially noticed in the halls.Dining: I sampled everything from the Savoy Grill to In-Room Dining to the Thames Foyer (for both breakfast and tea) and the American Bar. Impressive all the way around. The tea in particular was excellent and blew away the Ritz; Savoy Grill is a solid one-star Michelin.Location: London is big enough that I don't know if there is a hotel in a perfect location, but I was within walking distance of many of the theaters (Vaudeville, Savoy, Adelphi) and the Opera. Charing Cross is the nearest Underground station.Service: Impressive all the way through with some missteps. Turn down service was missed on two of the 11 nights and room service entered a couple of times without notice. The concierge services were notable (reservations at The Square on a moments notice). Tony the porter/bellboy was again very gracious, the master of casual conversation when necessary and professionalism when required.Cost: Appropriate for the overall experience.Summary: I look forward to visiting again in the years to come. The hotel was definitely due for refurbishment and I hope many of the staff return.

Oct 29 2008 	Old London luxury	I stayed here with my partner and his family for one night while we went to see a show. We were on a reduced rate due to family working there so I cannot comment on value for money but I loved this place. The rooms were so cosy and warm feeling, the bed was amazing and the whole atmosphere was just warm and welcoming. Not sleek and stylish but like being wrapped in a cosy vintage blanket. The bathroom was a problem, as pointed out by a sign in there, that the bath is very high and it's very easy to slipon the floor getting in and/or out. I read the sign and thought 'oh right maybe for oldies' and then went on to slip myself and I was and agile early 20s so be careful! However, I still give 5/5 as the service, location, atmosphere of the property was so enjoyable. Perhaps the location isn't right for everyone but it all depends on where you want to be!

Aug 1 2008	A bad location and the restaurants overpriced	The Savoy is one of those old grand hotels like the Plaza or Pierre in New York. But.....Our room was very old and again on the small side. While we had a lovely view of the Themes River, it is in the West End which is an awful location unless you are going to the theatre every night, which we only did once. The Grill on the top floor is very good as well as Banquette for something more casual. The only London hotel I've stayed in with an indoor pool which was very handy. The afternoon tea in the lobby lounge was decent and the bar was nice.

Jun 4 2008 	What a fantastic room	I stayed here for 2 weeks on a business trip and this hotel was fantastic! I was looked after so well. My room was huge (it was a corner room) and it had a large, updated, white bathroom with 2 sinks. I came home each evening to a fresh bowl of whole fruit that was always something in season. The staff were courteous and helpful. I can't say enough about this hotel. The location was okay. I do recall taking taxis everywhere and would take the tube to/from work each day in Canary Wharf, which took about 30-40 minutes. I felt very spoiled during my stay here

Feb 11 2008 	Fantastic	I stayed at the savoy last February with my husband and three year old daughter.On arrival we were greeted by warm welcoming staff who ensured our car was seen to immediatly they even handed our daughter a lovely teddy bear! When we got up to our room we found we had been upgraded to a suite and there were champagne and chocolates waiting for us (my husband had informed the desk that it was my birthday) this was all free of charge.The hotel is lovely rooms are clean with enormous beds and spacious bathrooms.To top it all off the view of the Thames was fantastic.Although pricey the Savoy is worth every penny and i cannot wait to return.

Jan 1 2008 	Nice Experience in an old hotel	Stayed at the Savoy for two nights in September. The hotel has a nice location, close to public transport. The hotel has an old school glamour to it, but you can also see that some things are worn and outdated. We prefer more modern hotels. The room was a good size and clean. We did the afternoon tea, and that was a nice experience. Overall a good stay.

Dec 13 2007 	Great Service	The Savoy is pricey - but well worth it - especially if you can get it on a "special" of one sort or another. Centrally located in downtown London, it is a great location for those who don't want to, or can't, spend their time (and money) going into and out of London. I was there with my 82 year old disabled father who was visiting London for the first time since the battle of Britian in 1943-44. He was treated like royalty by the staff and especially by the engineers !! When dad's scooter needed a replacement screw at 8pm - the engineering department, which is open 24 hours a day) had it fixed in a half an hour !! When we checked in at 8am, we were given a courtesy "early check in" and they even gave us an upgraded room, which was large enough for his scooter. In fact we could have put three or four scooters in that room !! The service and amenities are the Fairmont 5 star treatment that I have grown to love and appreciate. Evening turn down service, shoes shined at night, newspaper at the door in the morning, and a high speed internet connection make staying at any Fairmont a treat - and the Savoy was an especially delightful treat. Although the hotel is not entirely handicap accessible, the staff went out of their way to try to help dad get around. I understand that the Savoy is closing in 12/2007 for renovations, and that handicap accessibility is something they are going to try to remedy when it reopens.The hotel has one 110volt outlet per room, and they will loan you a voltage converter if you need more outlets. I brought a 6 plug "strip" and by using that we had plenty of outlets to charge the scooter, my camera, and the other devices we carried.While we were there I had a cocktail (or two) in the "American Bar" and saw dozens of photos of movie stars on the walls. It seems that this is THE place in London for the rich and famous to stay. It is rumored that Frank Sinatra would not stay anywhere but the Savoy when he visited London, and the same for Elizabeth Taylor. In fact, when dining at the upscale Savoy Grill, the wait staff may tell you which table was Sinatra's favorite, or which was the favorite for Winston Churchill. I met some folks at the American Bar that were Rolling Stones groupies. They invited me to a party the following evening at Simpsons on the Strand (one of three or four restaurants in the Savoy). I declined as the party didn't start until after the Stones concert was over with at 1am. The following morning at 5am the entire Rolling Stones came through the lobby and it was then that I discovered that I had declined an invitation to party with the Rolling Stones !! Next time I will be more prepared to rub elbows with the rich and famous.

Dec 9 2007 	Stately reputation no longer deserved.	This hotel needs $50m spent on it to re-qualify as 5-star. The rooms & amenities are incredibly old & tired. I stayed at The Savoy in the middle of a London heatwave & the air-conditioning in my room didn't work. The toilet didn't flush at all initially & even after repeated attempts to repair it, it didn't flush consistently. The battery in the safe went flat so I couldn't retrieve my passport when it came time to check-out. Far from being attentive, I found the service pretentious & insincere. I felt annoyed & imposed upon when a different member of staff knocked on my door every 90 minutes to ask if "everything was ok with the room". Especially as they were not the least bit responsive or helpful when everything was not "ok". Between the constant knocking & repeated attempts to repair the air-conditioning, the toilet & the safe, I felt like a member of staff was in my room 80% of the time that I was. The Savoy trades on its stately reputation, but it is no longer deserved.

Nov 17 2007 	Old Fashioned Elegance	Stayed for 3 nights and loved it. Our Junior River View Suite was really just a large-ish room, but we had a balcony overlooking the Thames and a postcard view of Saint Paul's. Bed and bathroom are super-comfortable. The place is definitely ready for its refurb, but still beautiful and graceful. Staff was efficient and friendly. The American Bar is probably my favorite hotel bar in the world, with its chatty and elegant host. Tea in the front restaurant is a wonderful experience.Location is extremely convenient for sightseeing and metro stops.There really is something special about the Savoy...you get a sense of tradition and understated elegance that is missing at other hotels. It has a bit less of a 'wow' factor than the Dorchester but I like it better for its clubby and traditional feel. I hope this feeling survives the refurb in December.

Nov 12 2007 	Ladies 	I like this Hotel. Its quintessentially English. It does white gloved afternoon tea. It has a hotel brolly and stand in the bedroom waiting for you and if you're a guy you wont be able to leave the men's room unless first brushed down by the attendant who'll find some fluff on your jacket somewhere that's for sure. Ghastly stuff that fluff!The Hotel is located right bang in the middle of London. It's five minutes from the Thames, a tube station, Covent Garden and Trafalgar Square. It is also close to more theatres than you could possibly hope to do in a long weekend including of course The Savoy Theatre which is right next door to the hotel. Guys you have all the gentlemen's menswear shops you could possibly wish for not even a cricket ball's toss from the front of the hotel. We had a room with a side view of the Thames but I'm guessing that the Suites at the back would all have a gorgeous view of the river, the London Eye and of course, Big Ben.The hotel is populated by Ladies and Gentlemen all of whom have a taste for the finer things in life. Yes there are people there too that have probably saved hard to enjoy this fine hotel once in their life. But these are people who know how to behave and how to enjoy great food and drink and abuse neither.The service is first class without being too deferential or sycophantic. They've got the balance just right. Ladies & gentlemen looking after ladies and gentlemen right through. Enjoy!

Nov 7 2007 	Not worth your money	Before we arrived at the Savoy we were very excited because we had heard some good reviews about the hotel and we usually prefer to stay at a Fairmont hotel when we travel. However, staying at The Savoy has changed our minds forever. We came across numerous issues and were very disappointed in the way we were treated by their personnel. We found the hotel to be very old - elevator was always stopping at the wrong floor, we had problems with our toilet - it would not flush. We called for servicing several times and they could not fix the issue. We asked if we could change our rooms, but the maintenance person said it was too late in the evening to do so and there were no rooms available. The staff was not very knowledgeable and was unable to assist us with our travel plans when we asked for directions. They kept transferring the call to someone else and it took awhile before they could find someone who knew the answer. We also found the staff to be misleading - they advise the client wrong/misleading info and try to blame the client for their mistake. We think the hotel is overrated and needs alot of work on the decor, but more importantly find personnel who are knowledgeable, friendly, helpful and honest. We will definitely not stay nor recommend this hotel to any of our family and/or friends. Maybe the Hilton would've been a better choice....

Nov 7 2007 	Absolutely Amazing	Almost impossible to describe with words. But I have to simplify I would say this is one of the best hotel you could stay, so much history, great location and service, perfect!Great restaurants within the hotel, and the best Sunday brunch I ever had in my life, from seafood to carving station, chocolate fountain, and the best part, unlimited Laurent Perrier Champagne.The hotel is closing for renovations soon, but it is definitely something to experience before the renovations are done, if you are going to London before mid-December you should definitely consider The Savoy as your hotel of choice. It might cost more than you like to pay, but I can assure is worth.

Oct 29 2007 	First Class	The Savoy is a first class experience from start to finish. It is due to close at the end of this year and reopen in 2009. I hope that it loses none of it's charm and character once the renovations have been completed.When we checked in, the friendly but professional receptionist advised me that our room was not ready. However, she advised that this would not be a problem and that she was upgrading us to a suite!The suite was the best hotel room I have stayed in within the United Kindom. Spacious and clean, it also featured a massive en-suite marble bathroom with a large bath and fabulous separate walk-in shower.The service was impeccable at all times throughout the hotel and the food was delicious.This was our third stay at The Savoy in as many years and we will definitely return when it reopens, providing that it does not lose its endearing character and charm.

Sep 20 2007 	Get there before the refurb	Having been to The Savoy a number of times for business meetings it was always a hotel I have wanted to stay at not only for the history but also for its location. However the cost has always been a little hard to bear. You can imagine my pleasure when idly scanning through hotels.com and seeing the hotels latest offer of 99 pppn including continental breakfast.I booked and treated my wife for a 2 night surprise visit. Apparently the cheaper rates are due to the fact that the hotel is closing at Christmas for one year to undergo a refurbishment. Does it need a refurbishment? Probably is the answer but it isnt tatty. More like faded but still impressive.From the moment we walked through the doors we were made very welcome indeed. The doormen were attentive and eager to help. The reception staff were efficient and courteous (showed us to our room, happens infrequently these days). This was the standard for the whole stay. The room was great if you like Art Deco. We do, and we loved it. From the curved doors to the best bathroom I think I have ever had in a hotel everything was just as I expected. Bathrobes, slippers quality shampoos and the like were also in the room. There was even a small stationary set in the desk.The continental breakfast was very good indeed. Smoothies and mini muffins to start with. Orange juice on tap. An almost limitless choice of teas and a basket of breads and pastries. More than sufficient and as always the service was of the highest calibre.We didnt eat at the hotel but a menu for the Savoy grill indicated a three course meal for 60. There are apparently another 6 restaurants in the hotel as well. We did have a drink in the American bar late on Saturday night and it was a nice experience. Pianist, nice atmosphere and, again, great service. Expensive? On face value yes. 30 for two cocktails. But I personally think its worth it.Finally the location. Two minute walk to Covent Garden and five minutes to Trafalgar Square and Charing Cross Tube. I dont think there is a better spot for tourists. If you baulk at hotel mini bar prices, we do at any hotel not just The Savoy, there is a Tesco express on the corner of The Strand and Lancaster Place/Waterloo Bridge 2 minutes away.You should stay at this hotel at least once in your life. You should probably stay before they refurbish it, its like going to the old Wembley, just one of those places you should see. You never know, Americans own it now, they may make a hash of the refurb and ruin it forever. No disrespect to any Americans intended.Service like this doesnt seem to exist in hotels anymore and Ive stayed in plenty all around the world for business and pleasure. I for one am prepared to pay a premium for it but its nice to get a bargain once in a while.

Sep 3 2007 	The Savoy in London's West End Theatre District	The Savoy isn't the reputed, 7 star Burj Al Arab in Dubai, Arab Emirates which costs 60 Euros just to step inside for a glimpse of its dazzling lobby. No, The Savoy, located on The Strand (in London's West End theatre district) has far more history and class behind it to set such pretentious and insolent limits. Frankly, a curious tourist could walk inside and enjoy the elegant, calming atmosphere of The Savoy without much ado. With limited budget, they could make their way to the "Banquette" and enjoy chef/patron Marcus Wareing's delightful concoctions. And, if you return the staff's politeness, you just might get the best seat in this informal setting--in the corner, in the far end, closest to the kitchen, overlooking the drive where one can watch the guests stepping out of their elegant cars and into the Art Deco style lobby of one of the most historic hotels in London. Opened in 1889 with 263 rooms and suites, The Savoy has seen history played out in its resplendent halls. Starting with the management of Cesar Ritz from Paris, chef Auguste Escoffier, and master of wine Louis Echenard (maitre d'hotel), the hotel became known for an unparalleled attention to detail and innovation. It was not uncommon to see guests such as Sarah Bernhardt, Lily Lantry, or even Edward VII seeking out the hotel's impeccable service. Sir Winston Churchill, Eleanor Roosevelt, Charlie Chaplin, and many many others have ventured through the doors of The Savoy. In 1953, Queen Elizabeth II was crowned. The Savoy threw "the ball of the century" on the evening of Coronation day.In short, few hotels could possibly try to replicate the feeling and ambience that are invoked at this fascinating place. And, for a weery travel such as myself, it was a relaxing haven where I found myself writing short stories and--in general--feeling creative. So many memories seemed to be floating around the halls and the rooms that it was difficult to capture all of the words and the emotions that sprange from brain to fingers. To add to the quality of the visit, the polite staff were everywhere greeting their guests, attempting to be helpful and welcoming. The rooms were not extensive but warm, inviting, relaxing, calming, clean, and carried the theme of Art Deco throughout. And, the garden, just steps away, was simply an extension of the hotel itself. Another of many ways to relax and enjoy the brief moments one has to be peaceful.Note: sorry but, due to renovations, the hotel plans to be closed from Dec/2007 thru 2009.

Aug 28 2007 	Fabulous hotel	We had a wonderful stay at the Savoy for our first visit to London. The location is so convenient, I would hesitate to stay anywhere else.Check-in was quick and pleasant. As we arrived about 9 am, our room was not ready, but they took my cell phone number to contact us while we saw something of the city. They took care of our luggage and we were off. We received a call about noon from the front desk that our room was ready.The gentleman who showed us to our room was very nice, asking about out plans and even made some suggestions.Our room was very nice, with a view of Waterloo Bridge. Soft sheets, plenty of soft pillows..but the real highlight is the bathroom! At the end of our first day, we were tired and achey. Well, the tub is big enough for two and filled so quickly, there is even a sign not to leave the room to avoid floods. With the provided bath salts, that tub really hit the spot. Of course, I later fell in love with the rainshower fixture. I have to figure out how to get one at my house.Continental breakfast was included and it was always delightful to enjoy it in the Riverview Restaurant. Once we saw how much it would have cost if it hadn't been included, we made sure not to miss it! The room is lovely and the service is great. If we wanted to upgrade to the full buffet, it would have been 5 pounds more per person, but we never thought that was necessary. We did need it delivered to out room one morning when we were taking the Eurostar to Paris for the day and needed to eat before the dining room was open. There was a 6 pound charge to deliver it to the room, but it was worth it.Another treat was the American Bar. We met a wonderful server Claire and a great bartender James. They helped us have a blast one night!The doormen were always great, the room was always spotless and the concierge always answered every question. One even made a great suggestion where we could find a good curry! It was very good, by the way. Oh, and we had a treat our first evening when they left a little cake in honor of my birthday, which we were celebrating on this trip! It was delicous. What else can I say? An historic hotel, especially if you appreciate Gilbert & Sullivan, with fantastic service! I would stay here again.

Aug 20 2007 	Great Hotel Great Location!	We just returned from our stay at the Savoy. We absolutely loved the hotel and had a wonderful time. Our rooms were recently remodeled and on the second floor right up the stairs and around the corner from the lobby. I think the room numbers were 201 and 202. Since we had our two teens with us, we had two connecting rooms. They connected through a hallway, not through the actual rooms. This meant we used one door to acess both rooms. It was not a family room. We actually liked these rooms better because they each had a bathroom. They did not really have views, but the rooms were big and the bathrooms were amazing! The rainshower was the highlight of the bathroom. It was so hard going from these rooms to the ones at the Westin in Paris. They just could not compare. The buffet breakfast every morning (included in our rate) was great! We loved the tea and hot chocolate. The staff remembered our names and greeted us each day. Everyone was nice and helpful. One complaint I would have is that when we checked in they asked me what newspaper I wanted delivered to our room. They did not tell me it would be an extra charge. When I checked out I found out they charged me three pounds a day for the paper. Other than that we loved our stay at the Savoy. I would absolutely stay there again. Just to let you know, they did tell me that the hotel will be closing in late December for a complete remodel and will open again about a year later.

Aug 17 2007 	A superb experience!	We stayed at the Savoy for two nights in August 2007. It was a 'hotel/show' package, but was still quite expensive compared with our usual practices! We were a bit 'apprehensive' about whether it would be 'posh', and whether we'd be the 'poor relations', having done a package. We couldn't have been more wrong! from the friendly. warm greeting from the commissionaire, to the reception staff, porters, maids, restaurant staff and everyone we met. They were professional, but relaxed, friendly, helpful, welcoming. It was a great experience!. Our package included continental breakfast, but for 5.00, (5.00!) we upgraded to the full and mignificent buffet! The room (de luxe) was large, with a huge bathroom. In no time we were really used to being in the Savoy! If you're simply thinking about it, just do it!!!

Aug 13 2007	Dissapointed	Took my wife for her 30 birthday as a special treat but i found the savoy to be anything but special. Having stayed at other various 5 star hotels in london we had high expectations of the savoy. We stayed in a one bedroom suite. The carpets looked like they had been layed around 30 years ago by blind men. The toilet didn't want to flush. The bed was small and as soft as a marshmellow and dipped in the centre. We both had back pain in the morning. The bath and a chip in the middle. The room needs fully refurbishing. We had dinner in the Thames Foyer at around 9. The restaurant was very quite but while the staff were friendly they was very slow. We didn't recieve the attention we thought we would considering the place was empty and costly. Overall the staff were helpful but i left this hotel wishing i had gone somewhere else.

Aug 9 2007 	Great Hotel Great Staff Great Location	I took my entire family to the Savoy for 9 nights in July and August and we were completely satisfied. We booked interconnecting rooms. One room for the children and one for my wife and me. The interconnecting family rooms dont have the views that the other rooms do, but they were large and very comfortable. There was no charge for a roll away bed for my 2 year old either.The location is great and we could move easily about London by going to the close by (5 minute walk through the Thames entrance) Embankment stop or the bus stop across the street. We could walk to the Waterloo Underground stop as well. We also walked to Buckingham Palace (35 minute walk through St. James park past Trafalgar Square) and the London Eye (15 minutes), Big Ben (15 minutes), Westminster Abbey (20 minutes). So, its location was very convenient.The staff was terrific. The housekeeping was a little different than we were used to, but I think it is an English housekeeping issue and not the staff, i.e. not removing glasses of water where there is a minute amount of water remaining in the glass.Our kids spent some time in the pool which is small and indoors, but they had fun and it was a nice respite from walking through the city.We read the prior reviews regarding the exorbitant costs for the restaurants in the hotel and avoided them all together. This proved fairly easy since there is a nice caf in the park on the Thames side of the hotel which we ate breakfast in a few times. Additionally, the hotel is very close to other cafes (Caf Nero, Starbucks), chain restaurants (Wagemama), and traditional English restaurants (Porters). So, one can easily go without eating in the hotel and save a few hundred pounds.Our only issue, which is minor and we hope will be resolved with the reconstruction to begin in December of 2007, is the labyrinth of hallways and stairs to get the elevators from the Thames entrance. With children and a stroller, it proved to be very tiresome. However, this inconvenience was vastly outweighed by the terrific service and amenities of the Savoy.

Jul 9 2007 	Excellent Location	What makes a 5 Star, a 5 Star?I personally would not rate the hotel as a 5 star, 4 star plus possibly.Don't get me wrong there is nothing at all wrong with the Savoy, it is a very good hotel in probably the best location in London. The rooms are of a large size, the beds are comfortably the bathrooms are great.For the cost of staying here, I was maybe expecting something a bit more. I suspect alot of the guests at the Savoy don't even think the rates are expensive. Especially when in the lobby I overhead an American trying to get theatre tickets for Mamma Mia that night. He was charged by the hotel about 80.00 per head, if he had walked to the theatre approx 10 mins away, would probably not have paid more than 50.00 per head. To the hotel's credit they did advise him of this.All in all a good hotel, where the location is second to none. To be honest the premier travel inn at county hall is one of the best least expensive hotels that I have stayed in London.
Jul 2 2007	Valentine weekend	A trruly 5 star hotel with impecable serivce and unfortunately prices to match. Afternoon absolutely fantastic but 35 a head as was breakfast at 25 per head

Jun 25 2007 	Love the hotel hate the mean spirited extra charges!	A special occasion demands a special hotel, and our stay at The Savoy delivered most of what I had hoped for when I booked the 1 night stay for me and my wife. The positives? A top welcome from Tony, the friendly and efficient doorman who took care of the valet parking arrangements for me and insisted on helping me in with my bags. The room itself was one of the art deco originals and although in need of modernisation it had all the atmosphere and charm that I had hoped for. Superb bed, with great linen and acres of room to stretch out. Massive bath, of Olympian proportions in a traditional and spotless marble bathroom. And binding the whole thing together was a sense of history and all round specialness that The Savoy has exuded for over a century.And the negatives? Unexceptional check-in and no offer of assistance with luggage  made me feel almost invisible as I staggered away with my bags towards the single lift serving guest floors. The extra charges for almost anything consumed, including the bottle of water left on the dressing table, with a Lewis Carroll style label around the neck, inviting the guest to Drink me! then to discover that a whopping 5.00 would be added to the bill. The minibar was astronomically overpriced  we debated the relative merits of opting for the 4.00 Pringles or the 6.50 nuts (we picked the nuts in the end, in a flourish of indulgence). And then there was the 1.50 phone charge for calling the Banquette restaurant, which is part of the hotel  deducted from bill with apology from check out clerk, but it just shouldnt have been there in the first place. The VAT on top of the published rate is just a racket as far as Im concerned, but so many of the better hotels seem to quote this way. And as a finale, there was the discretionary 5% service charge added to the bill, which I felt obliged to pay, even though the door staff and restaurant staff had been taken care of previously with adequate tips. Of course, I have the money and the amounts are relatively small - it's just a point of principle that when the little touches are all charged so ruthlessly, the sense of welcome becomes diluted by the strictness of the accounting process.A very grand hotel that gave us what we wanted, but the art of hospitality was a little thinner on the ground that I am used to in other parts of the world. Perhaps its just a London thing?

Jun 24 2007 	WOW The Savoy!	I still find it hard to believe we stayed at The Savoy!What a lovely, grand hotel, a true delight in every way.We found the service to be superb, they go out of their way to make you feel very welcome, and are not stuffy! Classically art deco throughout. Our room was spacious, with a FANTASTIC view of the Thames! Bathroom was beautiful with the memorable rainfall shower! Had room service evening meal in our room one night and the service was outstanding. Only negative was a few things looked a little tired, but that almost goes along with the whole art deco theme, so it excuses it...at least in my mind.Very expensive, but worth it just for the memories! Enjoy!

May 16 2007 	Great New Years Eve	We stayed here one night for new years eve.Great great great... cannot say that enough.Expensive but really worth it.We arrived at 2pm to check in but the room was not ready so they treated us to a full English afternoon tea on the house or drinks in the american bar. At 70 for 2, the tea was great and better still free!..The service at this hotel is the best I have ever had.

May 10 2007 	Brilliant! Loved it!	Wonderful...from the moment we arrived to the sad time 3 days later when we had to leave, this place is awesome. Kind, courteous staff, rooms beautifully done in grand elegance, crystal, glass, heavy drapery, and perfectly appointed lav. Robes, slippers, bath salts, everything we wanted and more! Quiet room, bed so comfy i could sleep forever, American Bar fun, lobby delightful (watched a couple become engaged!) everything perfect. Wish the dollar was better!

Apr 21 2007	Still An Excellent Hotel	Using the Fairmont web-site I booked online only two hours prior to checking in.As you'd expect, of The Savoy and of a Fairmont hotel, it is excellent. In particular the service is, as one would hope, attentive and careful. The room was large, well equipped and comfortable, and the bathroom was almost as big as the main room.All in all, a very good hotel, excellently situated on the Strand near to Trafalgar Square and Covent Garden, with all the airs of excellence that one would hope for.

Apr 20 2007 	Sheer class!	Booked a 3 night stay at the Savoy for our 10th wedding anniversary. We decided to splash out a little and book a junior Suite. We were personally escorted to our huge suite by very friendly staff. The view overlooking the Thames was fantastic.This set the tone for a wonderful 3 night break. The hotel staff were extremely friendly throughout. The Savoy is an expensive hotel. You have to expect things like food and drink to be expensive as well as your room. One thing you might not expect is that VAT is added on top of your room rate. So expect to pay at least 17.5% more than the rate quoted. On our final night we dined at the savoy Grill.The food was absolutely fantastic. The set 'sampler menu' is a 7 course delight!It costs 70 per head but is well worth it. But beware the drinks arepricey. Not many wines under 60 a bottle. With Service charge you won't get much change out of 250.If you stay at the Savoy you must expect top prices. In return you get the best Service I have ever experienced. But for a special occassion it's well worth pushing the boat out. Thanks Savoy for a great time we will never forget!

Apr 18 2007 	Excellent experience	We love this hotel, my partner & I alway stay here atleast twice a year sometimes with our daugther. The staff are as you'd expect from a 5* hotel as is the service. Mar 28 2007 	Beats sleeping on the embankment	On my last day at school as we were saying our goodbyes my headmaster offered his hand and told me that "You leave this school unscathed by education...I have no doubt you will eventually end up sleeping on the embankment." Mar 15 2007 	Wonderful but watch the cost!	We stayed here for one night only but it was lovely. The room was expensive but the rate did not include VAT which was an unpleasant surprise. I did fully enjoy my time there but I wish it would have been more like I imagined it before now,

Feb 4 2007 	Old and Overrated	I have stayed in a number of Fairmont properties and truly expected this to be the best of the best, based on the price and reputation of "The Savoy". Jan 27 2007 	Amazing just wonderful!	Arriving at the Savoy my boyfriend and I were greeted by polite and very friendly staff. Jan 22 2007	Lovely family weekend at the famous Savoy	Spent Saturday night there, mid January with my wife and the twins (5 year old boys). My wife had booked the hotel plus dinner at the Savoy Grill as a 50th birthday present. In terms of staff, I cannot fault the experience; from doorman through to the Maitre d' at the restaurant, and everyone in between, were all just wonderful to us and the boys: not pretentious or stuffy or haughty (a slight fear for us) just kind, engaging and helpful. They very much helped make the weekend a delight.We booked a 'special' family experience for 349 for two interconnecting rooms and breakfast. The rooms were lovely traditional style rooms, high ceilings, plenty big enough, elegant furniture and prints, marble bathroom, (mid-size but adequate). In all other respects the rooms were better than expected.We went swimming in a small but lovely swimming pool on the third floor, and ate dinner early at 5.45 with the boys in the famous Grill. The food was simply brilliant, and whilst the whole affair was little taxing on the two boys after about an hour, they managed well: they were treated to a tour of the kitchens, were given special treats by the waiters and were generally treated with respect - another fear we had had in advance was that they would be unwelcome in this rather sedate envrionment. If they were, we weren't to know it. The kids menu was not quite appropriate for the unrefined tastes of my two, but the kitchen were happy to supply pretty well anything we asked for - pasta with melted cheese for mains, a portion of carrots to start etc.Kids eat free there but before you all rush, the adults pay through the nose! To be fair, it was a special event for us so we didn't hold back on the glasses of champagne to start etc. The basic cost is 30 for the pre-theatre menu or 60 for the full menu, both 3 courses each (plus a couple of delightful extras thrown in). If we'd have been more careful we might have walked out with change from 200 but in the end...we didn't. And thus to the overall costs - from a tempting family experience offer of 349 spiralled to over 700 by the time we included the dinner, the valeting, the ridiculous mini-bar charges etc. all of which could be easily avoided if you wish to. That said, and given slight reservations beforehand, (I was expecting faded glory but we got art deco splendour) we had a delightful time; highly recommended.

Jan 15 2007 	Suite dreams 	I stayed here last weekend for my in-laws Ruby Wedding anniversary. Jan 8 2007	Robbed at the Savoy	I was staying at the Savoy on a business trip. My room was broken into and I was robbed of 3 laptops. They were too large to go into the safe. They were not out and visible, but kept in cases under a chair in the room. Apparently the thieves had used a housekeeping closet to access the roof and break into my window. Key records showed that there were a number of staff entries into my room that day, many of them after 6pm - when the crime took place. The hotel said it was turndown service, but when I entered my room at 10:30pm, my bed had not been turned down. The hotel offered me a "river view" room as consolation for my loss. I only wanted a room without a rooftop nearby. Not that it mattered... but there was no river view. I was disappointed in the hotel's response. All they kept saying was "this never happens here." Nov 14 2006 	Expensive and Disappointing!	Being familiar with Fairmont hotels and the historic reputation of the Savoy, I anticipated a wonderful stay. Unfortunately it was anything but memorable. Nov 1 2006	Anniversary Break - Very Good	Checked into a Junior Suite for one night for anniversary stay. Had a great time. Room was beautiful art deco, lovely room overlooking the Thames. Paid 500 including breakfast and a bottle of champagne. On arrival concierge very efficient. Drinks in the American bar were fun in the early evening, very buzzy, with a great atmosphere before people head their separate ways for the evening. The breakfast in the morning (River Restaurant) was the only disappointment. Had to queue to get in, and then there was a huge queue for the buffet which was not well-stocked and very disappointing. Almost like they were on some cost-cutting exercise (I can only believe this as they have had 100 years to get breakfast right, so people turning up for breakfast can't be a surprise). I've had better breakfast service in 3 star hotels. I did complain at reception, and was comped my drinks from the bar the previous evening by way of consolation. Oct 25 2006 	Fairmont Expectations Met Local Surprises Delight	It's definitely clear The Savoy has been brought in line with some of the standards set forth by Fairmont. It's definitely good to see there's another layer of quality management guiding the hotel. Check - in was fast and efficient, and I was led directly to my room. The key system was a little difficult to understand, I never quite had an easy time opening the door to my room. Housekeeping excelled with additional touches such as replacing half-used items with new, but not disposing of the half-used items, would also neatly fold clothes found strewn about. A service charge is added to the bill upon check out to cover maid service; it's definitely deserved and saves me the trouble of leaving cash in my room. As a Fairmont Presiden'ts Club member, I was entitled to a coveted banquette seat in Simpson's (next door), and given a free glass of champagne and some canapes while I perused the menu. Definitely a value add for even general members in the free Fairmont President's Club. I also wasn't charged for the internet usage due to my FPC membership. It's nice to see a free hotel frequent guest program begin rewarding guests with little extras right away, just for signing up. Fairmont definitely has my repeat business. The concierge staff shone particularly at this location. I reserved some theatre tickets long before my stay, but there was a problem with the time written on them, and I arrived at the show late due to the mistake. When I presented my problem to the concierge later that night, he offered to call the theatre to rectify the problem, and said he would contact me by 10 the next morning. By 9 the next morning, I had a call informing me the full price would be refunded. Excellent! I suspect I wouldn't have had such service directly from the theatre company myself without intervention. I didn't get to sample this service, but I think it's neat that the hotel room service offers takeaway cuisine for the plane flight. It comes in a Savoy cooler that you keep. The price is steep, but a good way to pamper yourself.

Sep 26 2006 	Great location	We stayed at the Savoy for two night prior to a cruise in early September. The location is the best. Sep 15 2006 	Great experience	This hotel was a great value for the money. The location was very good, lots of buses run along the Strand and its an easy walk to wandering through Covent Garden. Aug 27 2006 	6 great nights at the Savoy	Following a British Isles cruise we stayed 6 nights at the Savoy (Aug 20-26th) in a deluxe room at the Summer special rate of 209pounds a night.Our room was large & comfortable and cleaned twice a day (morning & turndown approx 7pm) loads of fresh towels, Savoy robes and the rainfall shower was wonderful (special shower head about 18 inches in diameter) . We had 2 beds with fluffy white feather duvets, they were wonderful & comfortable. The toiletries provided were very nice quality (shampoo, conditioner, lotion, bath/shower gel) There was a large, lit closet with a safe that was easy to use. You will even find a red "Savoy" umbrella to borrow.On arrival there was a tray of fresh berries & an almond cookie shaped like the Fairmont "F"The staff at the front desk & the doormen get to know your name so as I passed through the lobby they would always say 'good afternoon Ms ______. Very friendly and welcoming.One funny thing, the wake up calls are done by real people - not a taped message, so the first day I had a wake up call and when the phone rang at 8:00am I just picked it up and set it down without listening, then it rang again and I did the same thing, then it rang again and finally I said hello. The fellow said "Madame you hung up on me twice, this is your wake up call" I apologized saying I assumed it was a recording and he said 'Madame this is the Savoy, we do not have recordings" :-)Room Service was a fortune (ie) 20pounds for continental breakfast, 15 pounds for a sandwich. One night we were tired from touring and stayed in and ordered dinner - I had the most delicious Lobster Salad (24 pounds) and Chicken Curry (18 pounds) in fact it was the best meal I had in my entire UK trip (16 days). I also had a double bailies on the rocks (18 pounds)High speed internet is 18 pounds for 24hours and works great, you can also pay 30 pounds and get unlimited movies in your room for the same 24 hours. (to buy a movie on it's own is 13pounds each)The lobby is small but comfortable and lovely, the elevator (only one is tiny and looks like it's 100 years old - and it is) Like the elevator, the hotel corridors are very plain and un-grand, the Tea area looked lovely but we did not partake.The concierge was outstanding, he arranged a private tour for us and gave us vouchers to jump the queue at several venues (saved waiting in line) (ie) London Dungeons, we handed our Savoy voucher to the person at the door and were admitted immediately whereas there was a huge line up - at least an hours wait at the door to get in.The Concierge also arranged dinner at Simpson's in the Strand and told us we would be receiving one of the coveted booths and free champagne for being a Fairmont President's Club member, however on arrival we were just seen to a regular table in the centre of the restaurant and nothing special was done for us. I didn't say anything at the restaurant as I didn't feel like champagne anyway (we had just had drinks at the American Bar) but I did mention it to the concierge when he asked how dinner was and he was so apologetic and promised me something wonderful to make up for it if/when I stayed at the Savoy again in the future. Total for 2 drinks at the American bar = 26 pounds.The location of the Savoy is very convenient to the theatre district - you can walk instead of taking cabs. We saw Lion King, Mamma Mia, Phantom of the Opera & Mary Poppins, you are about a 5 minute walk from Charing Cross Station, 8 minute walk from Trafalgar Square and loads of restaurants like Pizza Express (which we loved)There is also a little Tesco express where you can get soft drinks, snacks, sandwiches, muffins etc... very inexpensively to avoid the high cost of room service. There is a Cafe Nero, & Starbucks within a 2 minute walk as well.All and all a great stay at the Savoy and I would definately recommend it, we were in room 404 looking out into the street & office building next to us. There are river view rooms available for booking at a high cost.See our photos

Aug 24 2006 	I rate this Number 1!	Finding a good hotel in London is as difficult as finding a good one in New York, but after countless visits to the UK over many years I have finally found the ideal hotel, The Savoy. It is ideally located on The Strand within minutes walking of several Underground train stations, theatres, Regent Street shops, and the lively Soho area. Remembering that everything is expensive in London, The Savoy represents excellent value. Despite many of the rooms and hallways needing refurbishment, the overall feel is of enduring quality, spotless cleanliness and service excellence. There are similarly priced nearby hotels that are newer or more hip, but my experience tells me that these are mostly a triumph of style over substance. And it is in the delivery of substance that The Savoy excels. The Savoy offers an excellent fitness facility gratis, several restaurants, access to high speed internet (prior to booking, become a member of the Fairmont Presidents Club and get this free, along with local calls), delicious food (the River Restaurant has an incredible buffet breakfast and the Savoy Grill is an experience not to be missed), and last but not least, warm friendly and abundant service. I have just spent a week at this hotel and it was far better than reviews here suggest. If you want a renovated room, then ask for it, but chances are it will have a limited view as was my experience until I was immediately offered the alternative of a junior suite overlooking the Thames. The suite wasnt renovated but it didnt really need it. In fact, the hotels charm is its original art deco features evident in the light fittings, patterned carpets, chrome door surrounds, etc. Also notable are Georgian style antiques in rooms and hallways, spacious rooms decorated in the Adam style with wall panels and elaborate architraves and cornices, and on the walls are extensive artworks some of which are for sale. In keeping with its Gilbert and Sullivan origins, in many ways it is a quirky hotel with a veritable labyrinth of passage ways that can seem gloomy, obscure entrances, and old elevators, including one with a red lacquered interior reminiscent of something out of The Mikado. This hotel certainly clicked with me and I will be staying there whenever I visit London.

Aug 23 2006 	No as good as it was	We stayed one night as we were attending a party and the Savoy was very close by. We booked two Fairmont rooms a twin and a double.
